+Dorian Leakey My point about the initial partition is that if Palestine 
would have accepted it then they could have had a successful state today, 
which wouldn't be constrained by things such as Israel controlling its 
water supply, as you had suggested.

I've not made the argument that Palestine should have accepted the 
partition. If they thought that fighting against it was the right thing to 
do, then I would have supported their right to do so (if I was alive at the 
time). They did this, or rather other nations did this (kind of) on their 
behalf, and they lost. The result is that Israel has continued to exist, 
and now the Israelis have their own right to defend their state. But, 
again, they should give up the illegally occupied land to Palestine.

Hamas is a response to Israel, but this doesn't mean that it is a morally 
valid response to Israel.

+Chill O'Ruygur Israel drops the leaflets and gives knocks on the roof. I

+Paul Phillips Israel is deterred by civilian casualties, which 
is indicated by the fact that they inform the civilian population of when 
they are going to strike a building used by Hamas to store or launch 
rockets. On top of that, the fact that they provide medical treatment for 
not only Palestinian civilians but also Palestinian combatants demonstrates 
that their policy is to minimise casualties on the other side. Obviously 
I'm not saying that this policy has been adhered to perfectly at all times, 
but having such an approach to the conflict is a huge contrast to the 
approach of Hamas.

And, yes, using your own children as human shields is absolutely 
disgusting. They are betting their children's lives on the superiority of 
their opponent's morality.  When this doesn't successfully deter a strike, 
the people who knowingly put their children within the target of the strike 
are equally as responsible for their deaths as the people who carried out 
the strike. Possibly more so, given that they had the option to move their 
children away from a strike on  military target and chose not to.

minimal force necessary to eliminate Hamas's ability to remain a threat. It 
has without doubt used excessive force at times, but overall has acted with 
restraint. The destruction and loss of lives are greater on the Palestinian 
side because Israel is successful at protecting its citizens and doesn't

at which side is using human shields and which side is deterred by them.

The way that ISIS treats whomever it perceives to be infidels is orders of

+Paul Phillips The Israelis have as much right to the land (legally) 
contained within Israel as the people of every other nation have to the 
land contained within their nations. The creation of Israel is not an 
unusual event in history. In fact is is rather typical of how a nation 
forms. 

Politics-wise, Israel isn't perfect, but it treats its non-Jewish civilians 
better than Jews have been treated in most nations throughout history. In 
fact, Israeli Muslims have more rights than do Muslims in pretty much any 
Muslim-majority state, especially those that base their legal system on 
Sharia Law. Whether or not populations have representatives in a nation's 
parliament and armed forces is a good indication of the degree of 
oppression that they could possibly be subjected to. A comparison between 
nations on this basis is completely valid, especially when it draws 
attention to the fact that many people are focusing their criticism on an 
objectively less oppressive state.
